7.23: but I observe another law in my members, at war with the law of my mind and making me captive to the law of sin that exists in my members.
7.24: Wretched man that I am! Who will rescue me from this body of death?
7.25: Thanks be to God through Jesus Christ our Lord! So then, I myself with my mind am enslaved to the law of God, but with my flesh I am enslaved to the law of sin.

8.1: But if Christ is in you, the body is dead because of sin, but the Spirit is life because of righteousness.
8.2: For the creation has been subjected to futility, not willingly, but because of the one who subjected it, in hope
8.3: And those whom he predestined, these he also called, and those whom he called, these he also justified, and those whom he justified, these he also glorified.
8.4: in order that the requirement of the law would be fulfilled in us, who do not live according to the flesh but according to the Spirit.
8.5: For those who are living according to the flesh are intent on the things of the flesh, but those who are living according to the Spirit are intent on the things of the Spirit.
8.6: For the mindset of the flesh is death, but the mindset of the Spirit is life and peace,
8.7: because the mindset of the flesh is enmity toward God, for it is not subjected to the law of God, for it is not able to do so,
8.8: and those who are in the flesh are not able to please God.
8.9: But you are not in the flesh but in the Spirit, if indeed the Spirit of God lives in you. But if anyone does not have the Spirit of Christ, this person does not belong to him.
8.11: And if the Spirit of the one who raised Jesus from the dead lives in you, the one who raised Christ Jesus from the dead will also make alive your mortal bodies through his Spirit who lives in you.
8.12: So then, brothers, we are obligated not to the flesh, to live according to the flesh.
8.13: For if you live according to the flesh, you are going to die, but if by the Spirit you put to death the deeds of the body, you will live.
8.14: For all those who are led by the Spirit of God, these are sons of God.
8.15: For you have not received a spirit of slavery leading to fear again, but you have received the Spirit of adoption, by whom we cry out, “Abba! Father!”
8.16: The Spirit himself confirms to our spirit that we are children of God,
8.17: and if children, also heirs—heirs of God and fellow heirs with Christ, if indeed we suffer together with him so that we may also be glorified together with him.
8.18: For I consider that the sufferings of the present time are not worthy to be compared with the glory that is about to be revealed to us.
8.19: For the eagerly expecting creation awaits eagerly the revelation of the sons of God.
8.21: that the creation itself also will be set free from its servility to decay, into the glorious freedom of the children of God.
8.22: For we know that the whole creation groans together and suffers agony together until now.
8.23: Not only this, but we ourselves also, having the first fruits of the Spirit, even we ourselves groan within ourselves while we await eagerly our adoption, the redemption of our body.
8.24: For in hope we were saved, but hope that is seen is not hope, for who hopes for what he sees?
8.25: But if we hope for what we do not see, we await it eagerly with patient endurance.
8.26: And likewise also, the Spirit helps us in our weakness, for we do not know how to pray as one ought, but the Spirit himself intercedes for us with unexpressed groanings.
8.27: And the one who searches our hearts knows what the mindset of the Spirit is, because he intercedes on behalf of the saints according to the will of God.
8.28: And we know that all things work together for good for those who love God, for those who are called according to his purpose,
8.29: because those whom he foreknew, he also predestined to be conformed to the image of his Son, so that he should be the firstborn among many brothers.
8.31: What then shall we say about these things? If God is for us, who can be against us?
8.32: Indeed, he who did not spare his own Son, but gave him up for us all, how will he not also, together with him, freely give us all things?
8.33: Who will bring charges against God’s elect? God is the one who justifies.
8.34: Who is the one who condemns? Christ is the one who died, and more than that, who was raised, who is also at the right hand of God, who also intercedes for us.
8.35: Who will separate us from the love of Christ? Will affliction or distress or persecution or hunger or lack of sufficient clothing or danger or the sword?
8.36:
“On account of you we are being put to death the whole day long;
we are considered as sheep for slaughter.”
8.37: No, but in all these things we prevail completely through the one who loved us.
8.38: For I am convinced that neither death, nor life, nor angels, nor rulers, nor things present, nor things to come, nor powers,
8.39: nor height, nor depth, nor any other created thing, will be able to separate us from the love of God that is in Christ Jesus our Lord.

9.1: And not only this, but also when Rebecca conceived children by one man, Isaac our father—
9.2: On the contrary, O man, who are you who answers back to God? Will what is molded say to the one who molded it, “Why did you make me like this”?
9.3: What then shall we say? That the Gentiles, who did not pursue righteousness, attained righteousness—even the righteousness that is by faith.
9.4: who are Israelites, to whom belong the adoption, and the glory, and the covenants, and the giving of the law, and the temple service, and the promises,
9.5: to whom belong the patriarchs, and from whom is the Christ according to human descent, who is God over all, blessed forever! Amen.
9.6: But it is not as if the word of God had failed. For not all those who are descended from Israel are truly Israel,
9.7: nor are they all children because they are descendants of Abraham, but “In Isaac will your descendants be named.”
9.8: That is, it is not the children by human descent who are children of God, but the children of the promise are counted as descendants.
9.9: For the statement of the promise is this: “At this time I will return and Sarah will have a son.”
9.11: for although they had not yet been born, or done anything good or evil, in order that the purpose of God according to election might remain,
9.12: not by works but by the one who calls—it was said to her, “The older will serve the younger,”
9.13: just as it is written, “Jacob I loved, but Esau I hated.”
9.14: What then shall we say? There is no injustice with God, is there? May it never be!
9.15: For to Moses he says, “I will have mercy on whomever I have mercy, and I will have compassion on whomever I have compassion.”
9.16: Consequently therefore, it does not depend on the one who wills or on the one who runs, but on God who shows mercy.
9.17: For the scripture says to Pharaoh, “For this very reason I have raised you up, so that I may demonstrate my power in you, and so that my name might be proclaimed in all the earth.”
9.18: Consequently therefore, he has mercy on whomever he wishes, and he hardens whomever he wishes.
9.19: Therefore you will say to me, “Why then does he still find fault? For who has resisted his will?
9.21: Or does the potter not have authority over the clay, to make from the same lump a vessel that is for honorable use and one that is for ordinary use?
9.22: And what if God, wanting to demonstrate his wrath and to make known his power, endured with much patience vessels of wrath prepared for destruction?
9.23: And he did so in order that he could make known the riches of his glory upon vessels of mercy that he prepared beforehand for glory,
9.24: us whom he also called, not only from the Jews but also from the Gentiles?
9.25:
“I will call those who were not my people, ‘My people,’
and those who were not loved, ‘Loved.’
9.26: there they will be called ‘sons of the living God.’”
9.27:
“Even if the number of the sons of Israel is like the sand of the sea,
the remnant will be saved,
9.28: for the Lord will execute his sentence thoroughly and decisively upon the earth.”
9.29:
“If the Lord of hosts had not left us descendants,
we would have become like Sodom
and would have resembled Gomorrah.”
9.31: But Israel, pursuing the law of righteousness, did not attain to the law.
9.32: Why that? Because they did not pursue it by faith, but as if by works. They stumbled over the stone that causes people to stumble,
9.33:
“Behold, I am laying in Zion a stone that causes people to stumble,
and a rock that causes them to fall,
and the one who believes in him will not be put to shame.”

10.1: For with the heart one believes, resulting in righteousness, and with the mouth one confesses, resulting in salvation.
10.2:
“I was found by those who did not seek me;
I became known to those who did not ask for me.”
10.3: For ignoring the righteousness of God, and seeking to establish their own, they did not subject themselves to the righteousness of God.
10.4: For Christ is the end of the law for righteousness to everyone who believes.
10.5: For Moses writes about the righteousness that is from the law: “The person who does this will live by it.”
10.6: But the righteousness from faith speaks like this: “Do not say in your heart, ‘Who will ascend into heaven?’” (that is, to bring Christ down),
10.7: or “Who will descend into the abyss?” (that is, to bring Christ up from the dead).
10.8: But what does it say? “The word is near to you, in your mouth and in your heart” (that is, the word of faith that we proclaim),
10.9: that if you confess with your mouth “Jesus is Lord” and believe in your heart that God raised him from the dead, you will be saved.
10.11: For the scripture says, “Everyone who believes in him will not be put to shame.”
10.12: For there is no distinction between Jew and Greek, for the same Lord is Lord of all, who is rich to all who call upon him.
10.13: For “everyone who calls upon the name of the Lord will be saved.”
10.14: How then will they call upon him in whom they have not believed? And how will they believe in him about whom they have not heard? And how will they hear about him without one who preaches to them?
10.15: And how will they preach, unless they are sent? Just as it is written, “How timely are the feet of those who bring good news of good things.”
10.16: But not all have obeyed the good news, for Isaiah says, “Lord, who has believed our report?”
10.17: Consequently, faith comes by hearing, and hearing through the word about Christ.
10.18:
But I say, they have not heard, have they? On the contrary,
“Their voice has gone out to all the earth,
and their words to the ends of the inhabited world.”
10.21:
“The whole day long I held out my hands
to a disobedient and resistant people.”

11.1: and cause their backs to bend continually.”
11.2: Well said! They were broken off because of unbelief, but you stand firm because of faith. Do not think arrogant thoughts, but be afraid.
11.3: For just as you formerly were disobedient to God, but now have been shown mercy because of the disobedience of these,
11.4: But what does the divine response say to him? “I have left for myself seven thousand people who have not bent the knee to Baal.”
11.5: So in this way also at the present time, there is a remnant selected by grace.
11.6: But if by grace, it is no longer by works, for otherwise grace would no longer be grace.
11.7: What then? What Israel was searching for, this it did not obtain. But the elect obtained it, and the rest were hardened,
11.8:
“God gave them a spirit of stupor,
eyes that do not see and ears that do not hear,
until this very day.”
11.9:
“Let their table become a snare and a trap,
and a cause for stumbling and a retribution to them;
11.11: I say then, they did not stumble so that they fell, did they? May it never be! But by their trespass, salvation has come to the Gentiles, in order to provoke them to jealousy.
11.12: And if their trespass means riches for the world and their loss means riches for the Gentiles, how much more will their fullness mean?
11.13: Now I am speaking to you Gentiles. Therefore, inasmuch as I am apostle to the Gentiles, I promote my ministry,
11.14: if somehow I may provoke my people to jealousy and save some of them.
11.15: For if their rejection means the reconciliation of the world, what will their acceptance mean except life from the dead?
11.16: Now if the first fruits are holy, so also is the whole batch of dough, and if the root is holy, so also are the branches.
11.17: Now if some of the branches were broken off, and you, although you were a wild olive tree, were grafted in among them and became a sharer of the root of the olive tree’s richness,
11.18: do not boast against the branches. But if you boast against them, you do not support the root, but the root supports you.
11.19: Then you will say, “Branches were broken off in order that I could be grafted in.”
11.21: For if God did not spare the natural branches, neither will he spare you.
11.22: See, then, the kindness and severity of God: severity upon those who have fallen, but upon you the kindness of God—if you continue in his kindness, for otherwise you also will be cut off.
11.23: And those also, if they do not persist in unbelief, will be grafted in, because God is able to graft them in again.
11.24: For if you were cut off from what is by nature a wild olive tree, and contrary to nature were grafted into a cultivated olive tree, how much more will these who are natural branches be grafted into their own olive tree?
11.25: For I do not want you to be ignorant, brothers, of this mystery, so that you will not be wise in your own sight, that a partial hardening has happened to Israel, until the full number of the Gentiles has come in,
11.26:
“The deliverer will come out of Zion;
he will turn away ungodliness from Jacob.
11.27: when I take away their sins.”
11.28: With respect to the gospel, they are enemies for your sake, but with respect to election, they are dearly loved for the sake of the fathers.
11.29: For the gifts and the calling of God are irrevocable.
11.31: so also these have now been disobedient for your mercy, in order that they also may now be shown mercy.
11.32: For God confined them all in disobedience, in order that he could have mercy on them all.
11.33:
and the wisdom and the knowledge of God!
How unsearchable are his judgments
and how incomprehensible are his ways!
11.34: or who has been his counselor?
11.35: and it will be paid back to him?”
11.36:
For from him and through him and to him are all things.
To him be glory for eternity! Amen.

12.1: being devoted to one another in brotherly love, esteeming one another more highly in honor,
12.2: But “if your enemy is hungry, feed him; if he is thirsty, give him something to drink; for by doing this, you will heap up coals of fire upon his head.”
12.3: For by the grace given to me I say to everyone who is among you not to think more highly of yourself than what one ought to think, but to think sensibly, as God has apportioned a measure of faith to each one.
12.4: For just as in one body we have many members, but all the members do not have the same function,
12.5: in the same way we who are many are one body in Christ, and individually members of one another,
12.6: but having different gifts according to the grace given to us: if it is prophecy, according to the proportion of his faith;
12.7: if it is service, by service; if it is one who teaches, by teaching;
12.8: if it is one who exhorts, by exhortation; one who gives, with sincerity; one who leads, with diligence; one who shows mercy, with cheerfulness.
12.9: Love must be without hypocrisy. Abhor what is evil; be attached to what is good,
12.11: not lagging in diligence, being enthusiastic in spirit, serving the Lord,
12.12: rejoicing in hope, enduring in affliction, being devoted to prayer,
12.13: contributing to the needs of the saints, pursuing hospitality.
12.14: Bless those who persecute, bless and do not curse them.
12.15: Rejoice with those who rejoice; weep with those who weep.
12.16: Think the same thing toward one another; do not think arrogantly, but associate with the lowly. Do not be wise in your own sight.
12.17: Pay back no one evil for evil. Take thought for what is good in the sight of all people.
12.18: If it is possible on your part, be at peace with all people.
12.19: Do not take revenge yourselves, dear friends, but give place to God’s wrath, for it is written, “Vengeance is mine, I will repay,” says the Lord.
12.21: Do not be overcome by evil, but overcome evil with good.

13.1: Love does not commit evil against a neighbor. Therefore love is the fulfillment of the law.
13.2: So then, the one who resists authority resists the ordinance which is from God, and those who resist will receive condemnation on themselves.
13.3: For rulers are not a cause of terror for a good deed, but for bad conduct. So do you want not to be afraid of authority? Do what is good, and you will have praise from it,
13.4: for it is God’s servant to you for what is good. But if you do what is bad, be afraid, because it does not bear the sword to no purpose. For it is God’s servant, the one who avenges for punishment on the one who does what is bad.
13.5: Therefore it is necessary to be in subjection, not only because of wrath but also because of conscience.
13.6: For because of this you also pay taxes, for the authorities are servants of God, busily engaged in this very thing.
13.7: Pay to everyone what is owed: pay taxes to whom taxes are due; pay customs duties to whom customs duties are due; pay respect to whom respect is due; pay honor to whom honor is due.
13.8: Owe nothing to anyone, except to love one another, for the one who loves someone else has fulfilled the law.
13.9: For the commandments, “You shall not commit adultery, you shall not commit murder, you shall not steal, you shall not covet,” and if there is any other commandment, are summed up in this statement: “You shall love your neighbor as yourself.”
13.11: And do this because you know the time, that it is already the hour for you to wake up from sleep. For our salvation is nearer now than when we believed.
13.12: The night is far gone, and the day has drawn near. Therefore let us throw off the deeds of darkness and put on the weapons of light.
13.13: Let us live decently, as in the day, not in carousing and drunkenness, not in sexual immorality and licentiousness, not in strife and jealousy.
13.14: But put on the Lord Jesus Christ and do not make provision for the desires of the flesh.

14.1: But why do you judge your brother? Or also, why do you despise your brother? For we will all stand before the judgment seat of God.
14.2: Do not destroy the work of God on account of food. All things are clean, but it is wrong for the person who eats and stumbles in the process.
14.3: The one who eats must not despise the one who does not eat, and the one who does not eat must not judge the one who eats, because God has accepted him.
14.4: Who are you, who passes judgment on the domestic slave belonging to someone else? To his own master he stands or falls, and he will stand, for the Lord is able to make him stand.
14.5: One person prefers one day over another day, and another person regards every day alike. Each one must be fully convinced in his own mind.
14.6: The one who is intent on the day is intent on it for the Lord, and the one who eats eats for the Lord, because he is thankful to God, and the one who does not eat does not eat for the Lord, and he is thankful to God.
14.7: For none of us lives for himself and none dies for himself.
14.8: For if we live, we live for the Lord, and if we die, we die for the Lord. Therefore whether we live or whether we die, we are the Lord’s.
14.9: For Christ died and became alive again for this reason, in order that he might be Lord of both the dead and the living.
14.11:
“As I live, says the Lord, every knee will bow to me,
and every tongue will praise God.”
14.12: So each one of us will give an account concerning himself.
14.13: Therefore, let us no longer pass judgment on one another, but rather decide this: not to place a cause for stumbling or a temptation before a brother.
14.14: I know and am convinced in the Lord Jesus that nothing is unclean of itself, except to the one who considers something to be unclean; to that person it is unclean.
14.15: For if because of food, your brother is grieved, you are no longer living according to love. Do not destroy by your food that person for whom Christ died.
14.16: Therefore do not let your good be slandered.
14.17: For the kingdom of God is not eating and drinking, but righteousness and peace and joy in the Holy Spirit.
14.18: For the one who serves Christ in this way is well-pleasing to God and approved by people.
14.19: So then, let us pursue what promotes peace and what edifies one another.
14.21: It is good not to eat meat or to drink wine or to do anything by which your brother stumbles or is offended or is weakened.
14.22: The faith that you have, have with respect to yourself before God. Blessed is the one who does not pass judgment on himself by what he approves.
14.23: But the one who doubts is condemned if he eats, because he does not do so from faith, and everything that is not from faith is sin.

15.1: “Rejoice, Gentiles, with his people.”
15.2: And so, having as my ambition to proclaim the gospel where Christ has not been named, in order that I will not build on the foundation belonging to someone else,
15.3: Now I exhort you, brothers, through our Lord Jesus Christ and through the love of the Spirit, to contend along with me in your prayers on my behalf to God,
15.4: For whatever was written beforehand was written for our instruction, in order that through patient endurance and through the encouragement of the scriptures we may have hope.
15.5: Now may the God of patient endurance and of encouragement grant you to be in agreement with one another, in accordance with Christ Jesus,
15.6: so that with one mind you may glorify with one mouth the God and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ.
15.7: Therefore accept one another, just as Christ also has accepted you, to the glory of God.
15.8: For I say, Christ has become a servant of the circumcision on behalf of the truth of God, in order to confirm the promises to the fathers,
15.9:
“Because of this, I will praise you among the Gentiles,
and I will sing praise to your name.”
15.11:
“Praise the Lord, all the Gentiles,
and let all the peoples praise him.”
15.13: Now may the God of hope fill you with all joy and peace in believing, so that you may abound in hope by the power of the Holy Spirit.
15.14: Now I myself also am convinced about you, my brothers, that you yourselves also are full of goodness, filled with all knowledge, able also to instruct one another.
15.15: But I have written to you more boldly on some points, so as to remind you again because of the grace that has been given to me by God,
15.16: with the result that I am a servant of Christ Jesus to the Gentiles, serving the gospel of God as a priest, in order that the offering of the Gentiles may become acceptable, sanctified by the Holy Spirit.
15.17: Therefore I have a reason for boasting in Christ Jesus regarding the things concerning God.
15.18: For I will not dare to speak about anything except that which Christ has accomplished through me, resulting in the obedience of the Gentiles by word and deed,
15.19: by the power of signs and wonders, by the power of the Spirit, so that from Jerusalem and traveling around as far as Illyricum I have fully proclaimed the gospel of Christ.
15.21:
“Those to whom it was not announced concerning him will see,
and those who have not heard will understand.”
15.22: For this reason also I was hindered many times from coming to you,
15.23: and now, no longer having a place in these regions, but having a desire for many years to come to you
15.24: whenever I travel to Spain. For I hope while I am passing through to see you and to be sent on my way by you, whenever I have first enjoyed your company for a while.
15.25: But now I am traveling to Jerusalem, serving the saints.
15.26: For Macedonia and Achaia were pleased to make some contribution for the poor among the saints in Jerusalem.
15.27: For they were pleased to do so, and they are obligated to them. For if the Gentiles have shared in their spiritual things, they ought also to serve them in material things.
15.28: Therefore, after I have accomplished this and sealed this fruit for delivery to them, I will depart by way of you for Spain,
15.29: and I know that when I come to you, I will come in the fullness of the blessing of Christ.
15.31: that I may be rescued from those who are disobedient in Judea, and my ministry in Jerusalem may be acceptable to the saints,
15.32: so that, coming to you with joy by the will of God, I may rest with you.
15.33: Now may the God of peace be with all of you. Amen.

16.1: Greet Apelles, who is approved in Christ. Greet those of the household of Aristobulus.
16.2: And in a short time the God of peace will crush Satan under your feet. The grace of our Lord Jesus Christ be with you.
16.3: Greet Prisca and Aquila, my fellow workers in Christ Jesus,
16.4: who risked their own necks for my life, for which not only I am thankful, but also all the churches of the Gentiles;
16.5: also greet the church in their house. Greet Epenetus my dear friend, who is the first convert of Asia for Christ.
16.6: Greet Mary, who has worked hard for you.
16.7: Greet Andronicus and Junia, my compatriots and my fellow prisoners, who are well known to the apostles, who were also in Christ before me.
16.8: Greet Ampliatus, my dear friend in the Lord.
16.9: Greet Urbanus, our fellow worker in Christ, and my dear friend Stachys.
16.11: Greet Herodion my compatriot. Greet those of the household of Narcissus who are in the Lord.
16.12: Greet Tryphena and Tryphosa, the laborers in the Lord. Greet Persis, the dear friend who has worked hard in the Lord.
16.13: Greet Rufus, the chosen one in the Lord, and his mother and mine.
16.14: Greet Asyncritus, Phlegon, Hermes, Patrobas, Hermas, and the brothers with them.
16.15: Greet Philologus and Julia, Nereus and his sister, and Olympas, and all the saints who are with them.
16.16: Greet one another with a holy kiss. All the churches of Christ greet you.
16.17: Now I exhort you, brothers, to look out for those who cause dissensions and temptations contrary to the teaching which you learned, and stay away from them.
16.18: For such people do not serve our Lord Christ, but their own stomach, and by smooth speech and flattery they deceive the hearts of the unsuspecting.
16.19: For the report of your obedience has reached to all; therefore I am rejoicing over you, and I want you to be wise toward what is good, but innocent toward what is evil.
16.21: Timothy, my fellow worker, greets you, and Lucius and Jason and Sosipater, my compatriots.
16.22: I, Tertius, the one who wrote this letter, greet you in the Lord.
16.23: Gaius, my host and the host of the whole church, greets you. Erastus the city treasurer greets you, and Quartus the brother.
16.24: The grace of our Lord Jesus Christ be with all of you. Amen.

1.1: Now I exhort you, brothers, by the name of our Lord Jesus Christ, that you all say the same thing and there not be divisions among you, and that you be made complete in the same mind and with the same purpose.
1.2: Where is the wise person? Where is the scribe? Where is the debater of this age? Has not God made foolish the wisdom of the world?
1.3: But from him you are in Christ Jesus, who became wisdom to us from God, and righteousness and sanctification and redemption,
1.4: I give thanks to my God always concerning you, because of the grace of God which was given to you in Christ Jesus,
1.5: that in everything you were made rich in him, in all speech and all knowledge,
1.6: just as the testimony about Christ has been confirmed in you,
1.7: so that you do not lack in any spiritual gift as you eagerly await the revelation of our Lord Jesus Christ,
1.8: who will also confirm you until the end, blameless in the day of our Lord Jesus Christ.
1.9: God is faithful, by whom you were called to fellowship with his Son Jesus Christ our Lord.
1.11: For it has been made clear to me concerning you, my brothers, by Chloe’s people, that there are quarrels among you.
1.12: But I say this, that each of you is saying, “I am with Paul,” and “I am with Apollos,” and “I am with Cephas,” and “I am with Christ.”
1.13: Has Christ been divided? Paul was not crucified for you, was he? Or were you baptized in the name of Paul?
1.14: I give thanks that I baptized none of you except Crispus and Gaius,
1.15: lest anyone should say that you were baptized in my name.
1.16: (Now I also baptized the household of Stephanas. Beyond that I do not know if I baptized anyone else.)
1.17: For Christ did not send me to baptize, but to proclaim the gospel, not with clever speech, lest the cross of Christ be emptied.
1.18: For the message about the cross is foolishness to those who are perishing, but to us who are being saved it is the power of God.
1.19:
“I will destroy the wisdom of the wise,
and the intelligence of the intelligent I will confound.”
1.21: For since, in the wisdom of God, the world through its wisdom did not know God, God was pleased through the foolishness of preaching to save those who believe.
1.22: For indeed, Jews ask for sign miracles and Greeks seek wisdom,
1.23: but we preach Christ crucified, to the Jews a cause for stumbling, but to the Gentiles foolishness,
1.24: but to those who are called, both Jews and Greeks, Christ is the power of God and the wisdom of God.
1.25: For the foolishness of God is wiser than human wisdom, and the weakness of God is stronger than human strength.
1.26: For consider your calling, brothers, that not many were wise according to human standards, not many were powerful, not many were well born.
1.27: But the foolish things of the world God chose in order that he might put to shame the wise, and the weak things of the world God chose in order that he might put to shame the strong,
1.28: and the insignificant of the world, and the despised, God chose, the things that are not, in order that he might abolish the things that are,
1.29: so that all flesh may not boast before God.
1.31: so that, just as it is written, “The one who boasts, let him boast in the Lord.”

2.1: For to us God has revealed them through the Spirit. For the Spirit searches all things, even the depths of God.
2.2: For I decided not to know anything among you except Jesus Christ and him crucified.
2.3: And I came to you in weakness and in fear and with much trembling,
2.4: and my speech and my preaching were not with the persuasiveness of wisdom, but with a demonstration of the Spirit and power,
2.5: in order that your faith would not be in the wisdom of men, but in the power of God.
2.6: Now we do speak wisdom among the mature, but wisdom not of this age or of the rulers of this age, who are perishing,
2.7: but we speak the hidden wisdom of God in a mystery, which God predestined before the ages for our glory,
2.8: which none of the rulers of this age knew. For if they had known it, they would not have crucified the Lord of glory.
2.9:
“Things which eye has not seen and ear has not heard,
and have not entered into the heart of man,
all that God has prepared for those who love him.”
2.11: For who among men knows the things of a man, except the spirit of the man that is in him? Thus also no one knows the things of God except the Spirit of God.
2.12: Now we have received not the spirit of the world, but the Spirit who is from God, in order that we may know the things freely given to us by God,
2.13: things which we also speak, not in words taught by human wisdom, but in words taught by the Spirit, explaining spiritual things to spiritual people.
2.14: But the natural man does not accept the things of the Spirit of God, for they are foolishness to him, and he is not able to understand them, because they are spiritually discerned.
2.15: Now the spiritual person discerns all things, but he himself is judged by no one.
2.16: “For who has known the mind of the Lord; who has advised him?” But we have the mind of Christ.

3.1: According to the grace of God given to me, like a skilled master builder I laid a foundation, and another is building upon it. But each one must direct his attention to how he is building upon it.
3.2: and again, “The Lord knows the thoughts of the wise, that they are futile.”
3.3: for you are still fleshly. For where there is jealousy and strife among you, are you not fleshly, and do you not live like unregenerate people?
3.4: For whenever anyone says, “I am with Paul,” and another, “I am with Apollos,” are you not merely human?
3.5: Therefore, what is Apollos and what is Paul? Servants through whom you believed, and to each as the Lord gave.
3.6: I planted, Apollos watered, but God was causing it to grow.
3.7: So then, neither the one who plants nor the one who waters is anything, but God who is causing it to grow.
3.8: Now the one who plants and the one who waters are one, but each one will receive his own reward according to his own labor.
3.9: For we are God’s fellow workers; you are God’s field, God’s building.
3.11: For no one is able to lay another foundation than the one which is laid, which is Jesus Christ.
3.12: Now if anyone builds upon the foundation with gold, silver, precious stones, wood, grass, straw,
3.13: the work of each one will become evident. For the day will reveal it, because it will be revealed with fire, and the fire itself will test the work of each one, of what sort it is.
3.14: If anyone’s work that he has built upon it remains, he will receive a reward.
3.15: If anyone’s work is burned up, he will suffer loss, but he himself will be saved, but so as through fire.
3.16: Do you not know that you are God’s temple and the Spirit of God dwells in you?
3.17: If anyone destroys God’s temple, God will destroy this one. For God’s temple is holy, which you are.
3.18: Let no one deceive himself. If anyone thinks himself to be wise among you in this age, let him become a fool, in order that he may become wise.
3.19: For the wisdom of this world is foolishness with God, for it is written, “The one who catches the wise in their craftiness,”
3.21: So then, let no one boast in people. For all things are yours,
3.22: whether Paul or Apollos or Cephas or the world or life or death or things present or things to come, all things are yours,
3.23: and you are Christ’s, and Christ is God’s.

4.1: We are fools for the sake of Christ, but you are prudent in Christ! We are weak, but you are strong! You are honored, but we are dishonored!
4.2: For the kingdom of God is not with talk, but with power.
4.3: But to me it is a very little matter that I be judged by you or by a human court, but I do not even judge myself.
4.4: For I am conscious of nothing against myself, but not by this am I vindicated. But the one who judges me is the Lord.
4.5: Therefore do not judge anything before the time, until the Lord should come, who will both enlighten the hidden things of darkness and will reveal the counsels of hearts, and then praise will come to each one from God.
4.6: Now I have applied these things, brothers, to myself and Apollos for your sake, in order that in us you may learn not to go beyond what is written, lest someone be inflated with pride on behalf of one person against the other.
4.7: For who concedes you superiority? And what do you have that you did not receive? But if indeed you received it, why do you boast as if you did not receive it?
4.8: Already you are satiated! Already you are rich! Apart from us you reign as kings! And would that indeed you reigned as kings, in order that we also might reign as kings with you!
4.9: For, I think, God has exhibited us apostles last of all, as condemned to death, because we have become a spectacle to the world and to angels and to people.
4.11: Until the present hour we are both hungry and thirsty and poorly clothed and roughly treated and homeless,
4.12: and we toil, working with our own hands. When we are reviled, we bless; when we are persecuted, we endure;
4.13: when we are slandered, we encourage. We have become like the refuse of the world, the offscouring of all things, until now.
4.14: I am not writing these things to shame you, but admonishing you as my dear children.
4.15: For if you have ten thousand guardians in Christ, yet you do not have many fathers, for in Christ Jesus I fathered you through the gospel.
4.16: Therefore I exhort you, become imitators of me.
4.17: Because of this, I have sent to you Timothy, who is my dear and faithful child in the Lord, who will remind you of my ways in Christ Jesus, just as I teach everywhere in every church.
4.18: But some have become arrogant, as if I were not coming to you.
4.19: But I am coming to you soon, if the Lord wills, and I will know not the talk of the ones who have become arrogant, but the power.
4.21: What do you want? Shall I come to you with a rod, or with love and a spirit of gentleness?

5.1: By no means did I mean the sexually immoral people of this world or the greedy people and swindlers or idolaters, since then you would have to depart out of the world.
5.2: And you are inflated with pride, and should you not rather have mourned, so that the one who has done this deed would be removed from your midst?
5.3: For although I am absent in body but present in spirit, I have already passed judgment on the one who has done this in this way, as if I were present.
5.4: In the name of our Lord Jesus, when you are assembled, and my spirit, together with the power of our Lord Jesus,
5.5: I have decided to hand over such a person to Satan for the destruction of the flesh, in order that his spirit may be saved in the day of the Lord.
5.6: Your boasting is not good. Do you not know that a little leaven leavens the whole batch of dough?
5.7: Clean out the old leaven in order that you may be a new batch of dough, just as you are unleavened. For Christ our Passover has been sacrificed.
5.8: So then, let us celebrate the feast, not with the old leaven or with the leaven of wickedness and sinfulness, but with the unleavened bread of sincerity and truth.
5.9: I wrote to you in the letter not to associate with sexually immoral people.
5.11: But now I have written to you not to associate with any so-called brother, if he is a sexually immoral person or a greedy person or an idolater or an abusive person or a drunkard or a swindler—with such a person not even to eat.
5.12: For what is it to me to judge those outside? Should you not judge those inside?
5.13: But those outside God will judge. Remove the evil person from among yourselves.

6.1: nor thieves, nor greedy persons, not drunkards, not abusive persons, not swindlers will inherit the kingdom of God.
6.2: For you were bought at a price; therefore glorify God with your body.
6.3: Do you not know that we will judge angels, not to mention ordinary matters?
6.4: Therefore, if you have courts with regard to ordinary matters, do you seat these despised people in the church?
6.5: I say this to your shame. So is there not anyone wise among you who will be able to render a decision between his brothers?
6.6: But brother goes to court with brother, and this before unbelievers!
6.7: Therefore it is already completely a loss for you that you have lawsuits with one another. Why not rather be wronged? Why not rather be defrauded?
6.8: But you wrong and defraud, and do this to brothers!
6.9: Or do you not know that the unrighteous will not inherit the kingdom of God? Do not be deceived! Neither sexually immoral people, nor idolaters, nor adulterers, nor passive homosexual partners, nor dominant homosexual partners,
6.11: And some of you were these things, but you were washed, but you were sanctified, but you were justified in the name of the Lord Jesus and by the Spirit of our God.
6.12: All things are permitted for me, but not all things are profitable. All things are permitted for me, but I will not be controlled by anything.
6.13: Food is for the stomach, and the stomach for food, but God will abolish both of them. Now the body is not for sexual immorality, but for the Lord, and the Lord for the body.
6.14: And God both raised up the Lord and will raise us up by his power.
6.15: Do you not know that your bodies are members of Christ? Therefore, shall I take away the members of Christ and make them members of a prostitute? May it never be!
6.16: Or do you not know that the one who joins himself to a prostitute is one body with her? For it says, “The two will become one flesh.”
6.17: But the one who joins himself to the Lord is one spirit with him.
6.18: Flee sexual immorality. Every sin that a person commits is outside his body, but the one who commits sexual immorality sins against his own body.
6.19: Or do you not know that your body is the temple of the Holy Spirit who is in you, whom you have from God, and you are not your own?

7.1: To the married I command—not I, but the Lord—a wife must not separate from her husband.
7.2: Each one in the calling in which he was called—in this he should remain.
7.3: and those who weep as if they do not weep, and those who rejoice as if they do not rejoice, and those who buy as if they do not possess,
7.4: But she is happier if she remains thus, according to my opinion—and I think I have the Spirit of God.
7.5: Do not defraud one another, except perhaps by agreement, for a time, in order that you may devote yourselves to prayer, and then you should be together again, lest Satan tempt you because of your lack of self control.
7.6: But I say this as a concession, not as a command.
7.7: I wish all people could be like myself, but each one has his own gift from God, one in this way and another in that way.
7.8: Now I say to the unmarried and to the widows: It is good for them if they remain as I am.
7.9: But if they cannot control themselves, they should marry, for it is better to marry than to burn with sexual desire.
7.11: But if indeed she does separate, she must remain unmarried or be reconciled to her husband. And a husband must not divorce his wife.
7.12: Now to the rest I say—not the Lord—if any brother has an unbelieving wife and she consents to live with him, he must not divorce her.
7.13: And if any wife has an unbelieving husband and he consents to live with her, she must not divorce her husband.
7.14: For the unbelieving husband is sanctified by his wife, and the unbelieving wife is sanctified by the brother, since otherwise your children are unclean, but now they are holy.
7.15: But if the unbeliever leaves, let him leave. The brother or the sister is not bound in such cases. But God has called us in peace.
7.16: For how do you know, wife, whether you will save your husband? Or how do you know, husband, whether you will save your wife?
7.17: But to each one as the Lord has apportioned. As God has called each one, thus let him live—and thus I order in all the churches.
7.18: Was anyone called after being circumcised? He must not undo his circumcision. Was anyone called in uncircumcision? He must not become circumcised.
7.19: Circumcision is nothing and uncircumcision is nothing, but the keeping of the commandments of God.
7.21: Were you called while a slave? Do not let it be a concern to you. But if indeed you are able to become free, rather make use of it.
7.22: For the one who is called in the Lord while a slave is the Lord’s freedperson. Likewise the one who is called while free is a slave of Christ.
7.23: You were bought at a price; do not become slaves of men.
7.24: Each one in the situation in which he was called, brothers—in this he should remain with God.
7.25: Now concerning virgins I do not have a command from the Lord, but I am giving an opinion as one shown mercy by the Lord to be trustworthy.
7.26: Therefore, I consider this to be good because of the impending distress, that it is good for a man to be thus.
7.27: Are you bound to a wife? Do not seek release. Are you free from a wife? Do not seek a wife.
7.28: But if you marry, you have not sinned, and if the virgin marries, she has not sinned. But such people will have affliction in the flesh, and I would spare you.
7.29: But I say this, brothers: the time is shortened, that from now on even those who have wives should be as if they do not have wives,
7.31: and those who make use of the world as if they do not make full use of it. For the present form of this world is passing away.
7.32: But I want you to be free from care. The unmarried person cares for the things of the Lord, how he may please the Lord.
7.33: But the one who is married cares for the things of the world, how he may please his wife,
7.34: and he is divided. And the unmarried woman or the virgin cares for the things of the Lord, in order that she may be holy both in body and in spirit. But the married woman cares for the things of the world, how she may please her husband.
7.35: Now I am saying this for your own benefit, not that I may put a restriction on you, but to promote appropriate and devoted service to the Lord without distraction.
7.36: But if anyone thinks he is behaving dishonorably concerning his virgin, if she is past her prime and it ought to be thus, let him do what he wishes. He does not sin. Let them marry.
7.37: But he who stands firm in his heart, not having necessity, but has authority concerning his own will, and has decided this in his own heart, to keep his own virgin, he will do well.
7.38: So then, the one who marries his own virgin does well, and the one who does not marry her will do better.
7.39: A wife is bound for as long a time as her husband lives. But if her husband dies, she is free to marry whomever she wishes, only in the Lord.

8.1: For if someone should see you who has knowledge reclining for a meal in an idol’s temple, will not his conscience, because it is weak, be strengthened so that he eats the food sacrificed to idols?
8.2: If anyone thinks he knows anything, he has not yet known as it is necessary to know.
8.3: But if anyone loves God, this one is known by him.
8.4: Therefore, concerning the eating of food sacrificed to idols, we know that “an idol is nothing in the world” and that “there is no God except one.”
8.5: For even if after all there are so-called gods, whether in heaven or on earth, just as there are many gods and many lords,
8.7: But this knowledge is not in everyone. But some, being accustomed until now to the idol, eat this food as food sacrificed to idols, and their conscience, because it is weak, is defiled.
8.8: But food does not bring us close to God. For neither if we eat do we have more, nor if we do not eat do we lack.
8.9: But watch out lest somehow this right of yours becomes a cause for stumbling to the weak.
8.11: For the one who is weak—the brother for whom Christ died—is destroyed by your knowledge.
8.12: Now if you sin in this way against the brothers and wound their conscience, which is weak, you sin against Christ.
8.13: Therefore, if food causes my brother to sin, I will never eat meat forever, in order that I may not cause my brother to sin.

9.1: Or doubtless does he speak for our sake? For it is written for our sake, because the one who plows ought to plow in hope and the one who threshes ought to do so in hope of a share.
9.2: I have become like a Jew to the Jews, in order that I may gain the Jews. To those under the law I became as under the law (although I myself am not under the law) in order that I may gain those under the law.
9.3: My defense to those who examine me is this:
9.4: Do we not have the right to eat and drink?
9.5: Do we not have the right to take along a sister as wife, like the rest of the apostles and the brothers of the Lord and Cephas?
9.6: Or do only I and Barnabas not have the right to refrain from working?
9.7: Who ever serves as a soldier at his own expense? Who plants a vineyard and does not eat the fruit of it? Who shepherds a flock and does not drink from the milk of the flock?
9.8: I am not saying these things according to a human perspective. Or does the law not also say these things?
9.9: For in the law of Moses it is written, “You must not muzzle an ox while it is threshing.” It is not about oxen God is concerned, is it?
9.11: If we have sown spiritual things among you, is it too great a thing if we reap material things from you?
9.12: If others share this right over you, do we not do so even more? Yet we have not made use of this right, but we endure all things, in order that we may not cause any hindrance to the gospel of Christ.
9.13: Do you not know that those performing the holy services eat the things from the temple, and those attending to the altar have a share with the altar?
9.14: In the same way also the Lord ordered those who proclaim the gospel to live from the gospel.
9.15: But I have not made use of any of these rights. And I am not writing these things in order that it may be thus with me. For it would be better to me rather to die than for anyone to deprive me of my reason for boasting.
9.16: For if I proclaim the gospel, it is not to me a reason for boasting, for necessity is imposed on me. For woe is to me if I do not proclaim the gospel.
9.17: For if I do this voluntarily, I have a reward, but if I do so unwillingly, I have been entrusted with a stewardship.
9.18: What then is my reward? That when I proclaim the gospel, I may offer the gospel free of charge, in order not to make full use of my right in the gospel.
9.19: For although I am free from all people, I have enslaved myself to all, in order that I may gain more.
9.21: To those outside the law I became as outside the law (although I am not outside the law of God, but subject to the law of Christ) in order that I may gain those outside the law.
9.22: To the weak I became weak, in order that I may gain the weak. I have become all things to all people, in order that by all means I may save some.
9.23: I do all this for the sake of the gospel, in order that I may become a participant with it.
9.24: Do you not know that those who run in the stadium all run, but one receives the prize? Run in such a way that you may win.
9.25: And everyone who competes exercises self-control in all things. Thus those do so in order that they may receive a perishable crown, but we an imperishable one.
9.26: Therefore I run in this way, not as running aimlessly; I box in this way, not as beating the air.
9.27: But I discipline my body and subjugate it, lest somehow after preaching to others, I myself should become disqualified.

10.1: nor grumble, just as some of them grumbled, and were destroyed by the destroyer.
10.2: No, but that the things which they sacrifice, they sacrifice to demons and not to God, and I do not want you to become sharers with demons.
10.3: If I partake with thankfulness, why am I slandered concerning that for which I give thanks?
10.4: and all drank the same spiritual drink. For they drank from the spiritual rock that followed them, and the rock was Christ.
10.5: But God was not pleased with the majority of them, for they were struck down in the desert.
10.6: Now these things happened as examples for us, so that we should not be desirers of evil things, just as those also desired them,
10.7: and not become idolaters, as some of them did, just as it is written, “The people sat down to eat and drink, and stood up to play,”
10.8: nor commit sexual immorality, as some of them committed sexual immorality, and twenty-three thousand fell in one day,
10.9: nor put Christ to the test, as some of them tested him, and were destroyed by snakes,
10.11: Now these things happened to those people as an example, but are written for our instruction, on whom the ends of the ages have come.
10.12: Therefore, the one who thinks that he stands must watch out lest he fall.
10.13: Temptation has not come upon you except what is common to humanity. But God is faithful, who will not permit you to be tempted beyond what you are able, but will also make a way out together with the temptation, so that you may be able to endure it.
10.14: Therefore, my dear friends, flee from idolatry.
10.15: I am speaking as to sensible people; you judge what I am saying.
10.16: The cup of blessing which we bless, is it not a participation in the blood of Christ? The bread which we break, is it not a participation in the body of Christ?
10.17: Because there is one bread, we who are many are one body, for we all share from the one bread.
10.18: Consider Israel according to the flesh: are not the ones who eat the sacrifices sharers in the altar?
10.19: Therefore, what am I saying? That food sacrificed to idols is anything, or that an idol is anything?
10.21: You are not able to drink the cup of the Lord and the cup of demons. You are not able to share the table of the Lord and the table of demons.
10.22: Or are we attempting to provoke the Lord to jealousy? We are not stronger than he is, are we?
10.23: All things are permitted, but not all things are profitable. All things are permitted, but not all things build up.
10.24: Let no one seek his own good but the good of the other.
10.25: Eat everything that is sold in the meat market, asking no questions for the sake of the conscience,
10.26: for “the earth is the Lord’s, and its fullness.”
10.27: If any of the unbelievers invites you, and you want to go, eat everything that is set before you, asking no questions for the sake of the conscience.
10.28: But if someone says to you, “This is offered to idols,” do not eat it, for the sake of that one who informed you and the conscience.
10.29: Now I am not speaking about your own conscience, but the conscience of the other person. For why is my freedom judged by another’s conscience?
10.31: Therefore, whether you eat or you drink or whatever you do, do all things for the glory of God.
10.32: Give no offense both to Jews and to Greeks and to the church of God,
10.33: just as I also please all people in all things, not seeking my own benefit, but the benefit of the many, in order that they may be saved.

11.1: Because of this, the woman ought to have a symbol of authority on her head, on account of the angels.
11.2: Therefore, when you come together in the same place, it is not to eat the Lord’s supper.
11.3: Because of this, many are weak and sick among you, and quite a few have died.
11.4: Every man who prays or prophesies while having something on his head dishonors his head,
11.5: but every woman who prays or prophesies with uncovered head dishonors her head, for she is one and the same with the one whose head is shaved.
11.6: For if a woman does not cover herself, let her hair be shorn off. But if it is shameful for a woman to have her head shorn or shaved, let her cover her head.
11.7: For indeed a man ought not to cover his head, because he is the image and glory of God, but the woman is the glory of the man.
11.8: For man is not from woman, but woman from man.
11.9: For indeed man was not created for the sake of the woman, but woman for the sake of the man.
11.11: Nevertheless, neither is woman anything apart from man, nor is man anything apart from woman in the Lord.
11.12: For just as the woman is from the man, thus also the man is through the woman. But all things are from God.
11.13: You judge for yourselves: is it fitting for a woman to pray to God with her head uncovered?
11.14: And does not nature itself teach you that a man, if he wears long hair, it is a dishonor to him?
11.15: But a woman, if she wears long hair, it is her glory, because her hair is given for a covering.
11.16: But if anyone is disposed to be contentious, we have no such custom, nor do the churches of God.
11.17: But in giving this instruction I do not praise you, because you come together not for the better but for the worse.
11.18: For in the first place, when you come together as a church, I hear there are divisions among you, and in part I believe it.
11.19: For indeed it is necessary that there be factions among you, in order that those who are approved may become evident among you.
11.21: For when you eat it, each one of you goes ahead to take his own supper, and one is hungry and another is drunk.
11.22: For do you not have houses for eating and drinking? Or do you despise the church of God and humiliate those who do not have anything? What shall I say to you? Shall I praise you? In this I will not praise you!
11.23: For I received from the Lord what I also passed on to you, that the Lord Jesus, on the night in which he was betrayed, took bread,
11.24: and after he had given thanks, he broke it and said, “This is my body which is for you. Do this in remembrance of me.”
11.25: Likewise also the cup, after they had eaten, saying, “This cup is the new covenant in my blood. Do this, as often as you drink it, in remembrance of me.”
11.26: For as often as you eat this bread and drink this cup, you proclaim the Lord’s death until he comes.
11.27: So then, whoever eats the bread or drinks the cup of the Lord in an unworthy manner will be guilty of the body and the blood of the Lord.
11.28: But let a person examine himself, and in this way let him eat from the bread and let him drink from the cup.
11.29: For the one who eats and drinks, if he does not recognize the body, eats and drinks judgment against himself.
11.31: But if we were evaluating ourselves, we would not be judged.
11.32: But if we are judged by the Lord, we are being disciplined, in order that we will not be condemned with the world.
11.33: So then, my brothers, when you come together in order to eat the Lord’s supper, wait for one another.
11.34: If anyone is hungry, let him eat at home, lest you come together for judgment. And I will give directions about the remaining matters whenever I come.

12.1: to another miraculous powers, to another prophecy, to another distinguishing of spirits, to another kinds of tongues, to another interpretation of tongues.
12.2: But now there are many members, but one body.
12.3: Not all have gifts of healing, do they? Not all speak with tongues, do they? Not all interpret, do they?
12.4: Now there are varieties of gifts, but the same Spirit,
12.5: and there are varieties of ministries, and the same Lord,
12.6: and there are varieties of activities, but the same God, who works all things in all people.
12.7: But to each one is given the manifestation of the Spirit for what is beneficial to all.
12.8: For to one is given a word of wisdom through the Spirit, and to another a word of knowledge by the same Spirit,
12.9: to another faith by the same Spirit, to another gifts of healing by the one Spirit,
12.11: But in all these things one and the same Spirit is at work, distributing to each one individually just as he wishes.
12.12: For just as the body is one and has many members, but all the members of the body, although they are many, are one body, thus also Christ.
12.13: For by one Spirit we were all baptized into one body, whether Jews or Greeks, whether slaves or free persons, and all were made to drink one Spirit.
12.14: For the body is not one member, but many.
12.15: If the foot should say, “Because I am not a hand, I am not a part of the body,” not because of this is it not a part of the body.
12.16: And if the ear should say, “Because I am not an eye, I am not a part of the body, not because of this is it not a part of the body.
12.17: If the whole body were an eye, where would the hearing be? If the whole were hearing, where would the sense of smell be?
12.18: But now God has placed the members, each one of them, in the body just as he wanted.
12.19: And if they all were one member, where would the body be?
12.21: Now the eye is not able to say to the hand, “I do not have need of you,” or again, the head to the feet, “I do not have need of you.”
12.22: But by much more the members of the body which are thought to be weaker are necessary,
12.23: and the parts of the body which we think to be less honorable, these we clothe with more abundant honor, and our unpresentable parts come to have more abundant presentability,
12.24: but our presentable parts do not have need of this. Yet God composed the body by giving more abundant honor to the part which lacked it,
12.25: in order that there not be a division in the body, but the members would have the same concern for one another.
12.26: And if one member suffers, all the members suffer together; if a member is honored, all the members rejoice with it.
12.27: Now you are the body of Christ, and members of it individually,
12.28: and whom God has appointed in the church: first, apostles, second, prophets, third, teachers, then miracles, then gifts of healing, helps, administrations, kinds of tongues.
12.29: Not all are apostles, are they? Not all are prophets, are they? Not all are teachers, are they? Not all are workers of miracles, are they?
12.31: But strive for the greater gifts. And I will show you a still more excellent way.

13.1: but whenever the perfect comes, the partial will pass away.
13.2: And if I have the gift of prophecy and I know all mysteries and all knowledge, and if I have all faith so that I can remove mountains, but do not have love, I am nothing.
13.3: And if I parcel out all my possessions, and if I hand over my body in order that I will be burned, but do not have love, it benefits me nothing.
13.4: Love is patient, love is kind, love is not jealous, it does not boast, it does not become conceited,
13.5: it does not behave dishonorably, it is not selfish, it does not become angry, it does not keep a record of wrongs,
13.6: it does not rejoice at unrighteousness, but rejoices with the truth,
13.7: bears all things, believes all things, hopes all things, endures all things.
13.8: Love never ends. But if there are prophecies, they will pass away. If there are tongues, they will cease. If there is knowledge, it will pass away.
13.9: For we know in part and we prophesy in part,
13.11: When I was a child, I spoke like a child, I thought like a child, I reasoned like a child. When I became a man, I set aside the things of a child.
13.12: For now we see through a mirror indirectly, but then face to face. Now I know in part, but then I will know completely, just as I have also been completely known.
13.13: And now these three things remain: faith, hope, and love. But the greatest of these is love.

14.1: There are probably so many kinds of languages in the world, and none without meaning.
14.2: Brothers, do not become children in your understanding, but with respect to wickedness be as a child, and in your understanding be mature.
14.3: And if something is revealed to another who is seated, the first must be silent.
14.4: But let all things be done decently and according to proper procedure.
14.5: Now I want you all to speak with tongues, but even more that you may prophesy. The one who prophesies is greater than the one who speaks with tongues, unless he interprets, in order that the church may receive edification.
14.6: But now, brothers, if I come to you speaking with tongues, how do I benefit you, unless I speak to you either with a revelation or with knowledge or with a prophecy or with a teaching?
14.7: Likewise, the inanimate things which produce a sound, whether flute or lyre, if they do not produce a distinction in the tones, how will it be known what is played on the flute or on the lyre?
14.8: For indeed, if the trumpet produces an indistinct sound, who will prepare for battle?
14.9: And so you through the tongue, unless you produce a clear message, how will it be known what is spoken? For you will be speaking into the air.
14.11: Therefore, if I do not know the meaning of the language, I will be a barbarian to the one who is speaking, and the one who is speaking will be a barbarian in my judgment.
14.12: In this way also you, since you are zealous of spiritual gifts, seek for the edification of the church, in order that you may abound.
14.13: Therefore the one who speaks in a tongue must pray that he may interpret.
14.14: For if I pray in a tongue, my spirit prays but my mind is unproductive.
14.15: Therefore what should I do? I will pray with my spirit, but I will also pray with my mind. I will sing praise with my spirit, but I will also sing praise with my mind.
14.16: For otherwise, if you praise in your spirit, how will the one who fills the place of the outsider say the “amen” at your thanksgiving, because he does not know what you are saying?
14.17: For indeed you are giving thanks well, but the other person is not edified.
14.18: I give thanks to God that I speak with tongues more than all of you,
14.19: but in the church I prefer to speak five words with my mind, in order that I may instruct other people, than ten thousand words in a tongue.
14.21:
“By those who speak a foreign language
and by the lips of others
I will speak to this people,
and not even in this way will they obey me,”
says the Lord.
14.22: So then, tongues are for a sign not to those who believe, but to unbelievers, but prophecy is not for unbelievers, but for those who believe.
14.23: Therefore, if the whole church comes together at the same time and all speak with tongues, and outsiders or unbelievers enter, will they not say that you are out of your minds?
14.24: But if all prophesy, and some unbeliever or outsider enters, he is convicted by all, he is judged by all,
14.25: the secret things of his heart become evident, and so, falling on his face, he will worship God, proclaiming, “God is truly among you!”
14.26: Therefore what should you do, brothers? Whenever you come together, each one of you has a psalm, has a teaching, has a revelation, has a tongue, has an interpretation. All things must be done for edification.
14.27: If anyone speaks in a tongue, it must be on one occasion two or at most three, and one after the other, and one must interpret.
14.28: But if there is no interpreter, he must be silent in the church, but let him speak to himself and to God.
14.29: Let two or three prophets speak, and the others evaluate.
14.31: For you are all able to prophesy in turn, in order that all may learn and all may be encouraged,
14.32: and the spirits of prophets are subject to prophets.
14.33:
For God is not a God of disorder but of peace.
As in all the churches of the saints,
14.34: the women must be silent in the churches, for it is not permitted for them to speak, but they must be in submission, just as the law also says.
14.35: But if they want to learn something, let them ask their own husbands at home, for it is shameful for a woman to speak in church.
14.36: Or has the word of God gone out from you, or has it come to you only?
14.37: If anyone thinks he is a prophet or spiritual, he should recognize that the things which I am writing to you are of the Lord.
14.38: But if anyone ignores this, he is ignored.
14.39: So then, my brothers, desire to prophesy, and do not prevent speaking with tongues.

15.1: But by the grace of God I am what I am, and his grace to me has not been in vain, but I labored even more than all of them, and not I, but the grace of God with me.
15.2: But now Christ has been raised from the dead, the first fruits of those who have fallen asleep.
15.3: And why are we in danger every hour?
15.4: and heavenly bodies and earthly bodies. But the glory of the heavenly bodies is of one kind, and the glory of the earthly bodies is of another kind.
15.5: But I say this, brothers, that flesh and blood is not able to inherit the kingdom of God, nor can corruption inherit incorruptibility.
15.6: then he appeared to more than five hundred brothers at once, the majority of whom remain until now, but some have fallen asleep.
15.7: Then he appeared to James, then to all the apostles,
15.8: and last of all, as it were to one born at the wrong time, he appeared also to me.
15.9: For I am the least of the apostles, not worthy to be called an apostle, because I persecuted the church of God.
15.11: Therefore whether I or those, in this way we preached, and in this way you believed.
15.12: Now if Christ is preached as raised up from the dead, how do some among you say that there is no resurrection of the dead?
15.13: But if there is no resurrection of the dead, Christ has not been raised either.
15.14: But if Christ has not been raised, then our preaching is in vain, and your faith is in vain.
15.15: And also we are found to be false witnesses of God, because we testified against God that he raised Christ, whom he did not raise if after all, then, the dead are not raised.
15.16: For if the dead are not raised, Christ has not been raised either.
15.17: But if Christ has not been raised, your faith is empty; you are still in your sins.
15.18: And as a further result, those who have fallen asleep in Christ have perished.
15.19: If we have put our hope in Christ in this life only, we are of all people most pitiable.
15.21: For since through a man came death, also through a man came the resurrection of the dead.
15.22: For just as in Adam all die, so also in Christ all will be made alive.
15.23: But each in his own group: Christ the first fruits, then those who are Christ’s at his coming,
15.24: then the end, when he hands over the kingdom to the God and Father, when he has abolished all rule and all authority and power.
15.25: For it is necessary for him to reign until he has put all his enemies under his feet.
15.26: The last enemy to be abolished is death.
15.27: For “he subjected all things under his feet.” But when it says “all things” are subjected, it is clear that the one who subjected all things to him is not included.
15.28: But whenever all things are subjected to him, then the Son himself will be subjected to the one who subjected all things to him, in order that God may be all in all.
15.29: Otherwise, why do they do it, those who are being baptized on behalf of the dead? If the dead are not raised at all, why indeed are they being baptized on behalf of them?
15.31: I die every day—yes indeed, by my boasting in you, which I have in Christ Jesus our Lord!
15.32: If according to a human perspective I fought wild beasts at Ephesus, what benefit is it to me? If the dead are not raised, let us eat and drink, for tomorrow we die.
15.33: Do not be deceived! “Bad company corrupts good morals.”
15.34: Sober up correctly and stop sinning, for some have no knowledge of God—I say this to your shame.
15.35: But someone will say, “How are the dead raised? And with what sort of body do they come?”
15.36: Foolish person! What you sow does not come to life unless it dies.
15.37: And what you sow is not the body which it will become, but you sow the bare seed, whether perhaps of wheat or of some of the rest.
15.38: But God gives to it a body just as he wishes, and to each one of the seeds its own body.
15.39: Not all flesh is the same, but there is one flesh of human beings, and another flesh of animals, and another flesh of birds, and another of fish,
15.41: There is one glory of the sun, and another glory of the moon, and another glory of the stars, for star differs from star in glory.
15.42: Thus also is the resurrection of the dead. It is sown in corruption, it is raised in incorruptibility.
15.43: It is sown in dishonor, it is raised in glory. It is sown in weakness, it is raised in power.
15.44: It is sown a natural body, it is raised a spiritual body. If there is a natural body, there is also a spiritual body.
15.45: Thus also it is written, “The first man, Adam, became a living soul”; the last Adam became a life-giving spirit.
15.46: But the spiritual is not first, but the natural; then the spiritual.
15.47: The first man is from the earth, made of earth; the second man is from heaven.
15.48: As the one who is made of earth, so also are those who are made of earth, and as the heavenly, so also are those who are heavenly.
15.49: And just as we have borne the image of the one who is made of earth, we will also bear the image of the heavenly.
15.51: Behold, I tell you a mystery: we will not all fall asleep, but we will all be changed,
15.52: in a moment, in the blink of an eye, at the last trumpet. For the trumpet will sound, and the dead will be raised imperishable, and we will be changed.
15.53: For it is necessary for this perishable body to put on incorruptibility, and this mortal body to put on immortality.
15.54:
But whenever this perishable body puts on incorruptibility and this mortal body puts on immortality, then the saying that is written will take place:
“Death is swallowed up in victory.
15.55:
Where, O death, is your victory?
Where, O death, is your sting?
15.56: Now the sting of death is sin, and the power of sin is the law.
15.57: But thanks be to God, who gives us the victory through our Lord Jesus Christ!
15.58: So then, my dear brothers, be steadfast, immovable, always abounding in the work of the Lord, because you know that your labor is not in vain in the Lord.

16.1: But if Timothy comes, see that he is with you without cause to fear, for he is carrying out the Lord’s work, as I also am.
16.2: All the brothers greet you. Greet one another with a holy kiss.
16.3: And whenever I arrive, whomever you approve by letters, I will send these to take your gift to Jerusalem.
16.4: And if it is worthwhile for me to go also, they will travel with me.
16.5: But I will come to you whenever I go through Macedonia (for I am going through Macedonia),
16.6: and perhaps I will stay with you, or even spend the winter, so that you may send me on my way wherever I may go.
16.7: For I do not want to see you now in passing, for I hope to remain some time with you, if the Lord allows it.
16.8: But I will remain in Ephesus until Pentecost,
16.9: for a great and effective door has opened for me, and there are many opponents.
16.11: Therefore do not let anyone disdain him, but send him on his way in peace in order that he may come to me, for I am expecting him with the brothers.
16.12: Now concerning Apollos our brother, I urged him many times that he should come to you with the brothers, and he was not at all willing that he should come now, but he will come whenever he has an opportunity.
16.13: Be on the alert, stand firm in the faith, act courageously, be strong.
16.14: All your actions must be done in love.
16.15: Now I urge you, brothers—you know about the household of Stephanas, that they are the first fruits of Achaia, and they have devoted themselves to the ministry for the saints—
16.16: that you also be subject to such people, and to all those who work together and labor.
16.17: Now I rejoice over the arrival of Stephanas and Fortunatus and Achaicus, because these make up for your absence,
16.18: for they have refreshed my spirit and yours. Therefore recognize such people.
16.19: The churches of the province of Asia greet you. Aquila and Prisca greet you in the Lord many times, together with the church in their house.
16.21: The greeting is by my hand—Paul’s.
16.22: If anyone does not love the Lord, let him be accursed. O Lord, come!
16.23: The grace of the Lord Jesus be with you.
16.24: My love be with all of you in Christ Jesus.

1.3: Blessed is the God and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ, the Father of mercies and God of all comfort,
1.4: who comforts us in all our affliction, so that we may be able to comfort those who are in all affliction with the comfort with which we ourselves are comforted by God.

1.11: while you also join in helping on our behalf by prayer, so that thanks may be given on our behalf by many persons for this gracious gift given to us through the help of many.
1.12: For our reason for boasting is this: the testimony of our conscience that we conducted ourselves in the world, and especially toward you, in holiness and purity of motive from God, not in merely human wisdom, but by the grace of God.
1.13: For we are not writing anything else to you except what you can read or also understand. But I hope that you will understand completely,
1.14: just as you have also understood us in part, that we are your reason for boasting, just as you are also ours in the day of our Lord Jesus.
1.15: And with this confidence, I was wanting to come to you previously, in order that you may have a second proof of my goodwill,
1.16: and through you to go to Macedonia, and to come to you again from Macedonia, and to be sent on my way by you to Judea.

1.18: But God is faithful, so that our word to you is not “yes” and “no.”
1.19: For the Son of God, Jesus Christ, the one who was proclaimed among you by us, by me and Silvanus and Timothy, did not become “yes” and “no,” but has become “yes” in him.
1.21: Now the one who establishes us together with you in Christ and who anoints us is God,
1.22: who also sealed us and gave the down payment of the Spirit in our hearts.

2.3: And I wrote this very thing in order that when I came, I would not experience sorrow from those who ought to have made me glad, because I have confidence about you all, that my joy belongs to all of you.
2.4: For out of great distress and anguish of heart I wrote to you through many tears, not so that you may be caused to be sad, but so that you may know the love that I have especially for you.
2.5: But if anyone has caused sorrow, he has not caused me sorrow, but to some degree—in order not to say too much—to all of you.
2.6: This punishment by the majority is sufficient for such a person.
2.7: So then, you should rather forgive and comfort him, lest somehow this person should be overwhelmed by excessive sorrow.
2.8: Therefore I urge you to confirm your love for him.
2.9: Because for this reason also I wrote, in order that I could know your proven character, whether you are obedient in everything.
2.11: in order that we may not be exploited by Satan (for we are not ignorant of his schemes).

2.14: But thanks be to God, who always leads us in triumphal procession in Christ, and who reveals the fragrance of the knowledge of him through us in every place.

3.1: For indeed what had been glorified has not been glorified in this case, on account of the glory that surpasses it.
